strategies.name: Higher-Order Learning
strategies.description: Focus on understanding relationships and concepts rather than memorizing isolated facts. True learning happens when you can explain WHY something works, not just WHAT it is.
strategies.when_to_apply: Always - this is the foundation of effective learning
tutor_prompts: Ask 'Why does this work?' not just 'What is this?'
Challenge the student to explain the reasoning
Connect new concepts to previously learned material
Avoid accepting rote answers without understanding

surface_learning: Can recite definition but can't explain it

strategies.name: Active Recall
strategies.description: Actively stimulate memory during learning by testing yourself rather than passively reviewing material. The effort of retrieval strengthens memory traces.
strategies.when_to_apply: After initial encoding, during review sessions, exam preparation
tutor_prompts: Before explaining, ask: 'What do you already know about this?'
After teaching: 'Can you explain that back to me?'
Use questions to check understanding, not leading hints
Create mini-quizzes throughout the session

strategies.name: Spaced Repetition
strategies.description: Review material at increasing intervals over time. The spacing effect shows that distributed practice leads to better long-term retention than massed practice.
key_principles: Spacing effect: spread practice over time
Increasing intervals: 1 day → 3 days → 1 week → 2 weeks
Combine with active recall for maximum effect
tutor_prompts: Let's revisit what we covered last time
What do you remember from our previous session?
Schedule review of challenging concepts

strategies.name: Deep Encoding Strategies
strategies.description: How you initially process information determines how well you'll remember it. Deeper processing = stronger memory. Surface processing = weak memory.

levels_of_processing.deep: Relating to personal experience, generating examples, teaching others, creating analogies

tutor_prompts: Can you think of a real-world example of this?
How does this relate to something you already know?
If you had to teach this to a friend, how would you explain it?
What would happen if [variable] changed?

strategies.name: Avoiding Illusion of Competence
strategies.description: Students often overestimate their understanding because recognition feels like knowing. True competence requires being able to retrieve and apply without cues.
warning_signs: Can follow along but can't reproduce independently
solutions: Explain concepts without looking at notes
Practice in conditions similar to actual use
tutor_prompts: Before I explain more, try to solve this on your own
Close your notes and tell me what you remember
Rate your confidence, then let's test it
Challenge: explain this without using the textbook terms

strategies.name: Interleaving Practice
strategies.description: Mix different types of problems or topics during practice rather than blocking (practicing one type repeatedly). This builds discrimination skills and transfer.
strategies.when_to_apply: Practice sessions, exam prep, skill development
tutor_prompts: Let's mix in some different problem types
Without looking at the chapter, what approach would you use?
This combines concepts from our last few topics

strategies.name: Elaborative Interrogation
strategies.description: Constantly ask 'Why?' and 'How?' questions about the material. Generating explanations for facts enhances understanding and memory.
tutor_prompts: Why do you think that's the case?
What's the underlying reason?
How would you explain why this happens?
What mechanism makes this work?

strategies.name: Concrete Examples
strategies.description: Abstract concepts become clear through concrete examples. Multiple varied examples help build robust understanding.
tutor_prompts: Let me give you an example...
Can you think of another example?
How about an example from everyday life?
What would be a counter-example?

strategies.name: Dual Coding
strategies.description: Combine verbal and visual information. Processing information in multiple formats creates stronger and more retrievable memories.
tutor_prompts: Let me draw this out...
Can you visualize how this works?
What would a diagram of this look like?
Picture this scenario...

strategies.name: Self-Explanation
strategies.description: Explain material to yourself as you learn. Articulating your understanding reveals gaps and deepens processing.
key_principles: Fill gaps as you find them
tutor_prompts: Walk me through your thinking
Explain what you're doing at each step
What's happening here and why?
Teach this back to me

meta.usage_note: These strategies should be woven naturally into tutoring. Don't announce them - apply them.
meta.combine: Most effective when multiple strategies are used together
